p: The costs for non-U.S. countries are similarly large. The approximately 600,000 premature deaths and the diseases caused by air pollution in the WHO European Region in 2010 cost European economies an estimated US$1.6 trillion in 2010 ( WHO Regional Office for Europe and OECD 2015). As recently reviewed in Lancet, the estimated cost of ambient air pollution in terms of the value of lives lost and ill health in OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) countries, plus India and China, is > US$3.5 trillion annually ( Watts et al. 2015). The Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) Program estimates that achieving air quality targets for Europe has a benefitâ€“cost ratio of between 6 and 19 ( Hutton and Menne 2014).
